diff.*:
Line 3: Line 3:      
'''Wisdom''' is the judicious study and application of knowledge. It is a deep understanding and realization of people, things, events or situations, resulting in the ability to apply perceptions, judgments and actions in keeping with this understanding. It often requires control of one's emotional reactions (the "[[Passions (philosophy)|passions]]") so that universal principles, reason and knowledge prevail to determine one's actions. Wisdom is also the comprehension of what is true coupled with optimum judgment as to action. Synonyms include: sagacity, discernment, or insight.
 
'''Wisdom''' is the judicious study and application of knowledge. It is a deep understanding and realization of people, things, events or situations, resulting in the ability to apply perceptions, judgments and actions in keeping with this understanding. It often requires control of one's emotional reactions (the "[[Passions (philosophy)|passions]]") so that universal principles, reason and knowledge prevail to determine one's actions. Wisdom is also the comprehension of what is true coupled with optimum judgment as to action. Synonyms include: sagacity, discernment, or insight.
−
+
 
==Philosophical perspectives of wisdom==
 
==Philosophical perspectives of wisdom==
 
[[File:Efez Celsus Library 3 RB.jpg|thumb|[[Personification]] of wisdom (in [[Greek language|Greek]], "''Σοφία''" or "''[[Sophia (wisdom)|Sophia]]''") at the [[Celsus Library]] in [[Ephesus]], [[Turkey]].]]
 
[[File:Efez Celsus Library 3 RB.jpg|thumb|[[Personification]] of wisdom (in [[Greek language|Greek]], "''Σοφία''" or "''[[Sophia (wisdom)|Sophia]]''") at the [[Celsus Library]] in [[Ephesus]], [[Turkey]].]]
Line 17: Line 17:  
In the [[Inuit]] tradition, developing wisdom was one of the aims of teaching. An Inuit Elder said that a person became wise when they could see what needed to be done and do it successfully without being told what to do.
 
In the [[Inuit]] tradition, developing wisdom was one of the aims of teaching. An Inuit Elder said that a person became wise when they could see what needed to be done and do it successfully without being told what to do.
    −
The Native American's philosophy about being a part of the natural environment contrasted to the European's culture of conquering nature's gifts. The Native American's wisdom about maintaining balance ecologically and socially was a common-sense approach to protecting and conserving natural resources.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=Thewildwest.org|date=2010|title=Native American wisdom|url=http://www.thewildwest.org/nativeamericans/nativeamericanwisdom.html}}</ref>
+
The Native American's philosophy about being a part of the natural environment contrasted to the European's culture of conquering nature's gifts. The Native American's wisdom about maintaining balance ecologically and socially was a common-sense approach to protecting and conserving natural resources.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=Thewildwest.org|year=2010|title=Native American wisdom|url=http://www.thewildwest.org/nativeamericans/nativeamericanwisdom.html}}</ref>

Measurement instruments that use these criteria have acceptable to good [[internal consistency]] and low to moderate [[test-retest]] [[Reliability (statistics)|reliability]] (''[[Pearson product-moment correlation coefficient|r]]'' in the range of 0.35 to 0.67).<ref name="CSVperspective">{{cite book|last=Harter|first=Andrew C.|title=[[Character Strengths and Virtues (book)|Character Strengths and Virtues: A Handbook and Classification]]|editor=Peterson, Christopher and [[Martin Seligman|Seligman, Martin E. P.]]|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|chapter=8|year=2004|location=Oxford|pages=181–196|isbn=0-19-516701-5}}</ref>
    −
[[John Vervaeke]] has argued for a cognitive science of wisdom and argues that basic [[relevance realization]] processes that underlie cognition, when fed back onto themselves and made self-referential lead to the enhanced insight abilities we associated with wisdom. <ref>{{cite book|last=Ferrari|first=Michel|title=The Scientific Study of Personal Wisdom.|year=2012|publisher=Springer Verlag|isbn=978-9048192304}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|last=Vervaeke|first=John|title=The Cognitive Science of Wisdom|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ti4Kj8TcEgk|publisher=Mind Matters Conference|accessdate=13 April 2013}}</ref>
+
[[John Vervaeke]] has argued for a cognitive science of wisdom and argues that basic [[relevance realization]] processes that underlie cognition, when fed back onto themselves and made self-referential lead to the enhanced insight abilities we associated with wisdom.<ref>{{cite book|last=Ferrari|first=Michel|title=The Scientific Study of Personal Wisdom.|year=2012|publisher=Springer Verlag|isbn=978-9048192304}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Vervaeke|first=John|title=The Cognitive Science of Wisdom|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ti4Kj8TcEgk|publisher=Mind Matters Conference|accessdate=13 April 2013}}</ref>

Line 48: Line 48:  
===Bahai Faith===
 
===Bahai Faith===
 
Wisdom and the acquiring of it is mentioned frequently in the Bahai Scriptures. According to the scriptures
 
Wisdom and the acquiring of it is mentioned frequently in the Bahai Scriptures. According to the scriptures
−
"The essence of wisdom is the fear of God, the dread of His scourge and punishment, and the apprehension of His justice and decree."<ref>{{cite web|title=Bahai Reference Library|url=http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/b/TB/tb-11.html|work=Tablets of Bahá’u’lláh Revealed After the Kitáb-i-Aqdas|publisher=US Bahá’í Publishing Trust, 1988 pocket-size edition|accessdate=19 March 2013}}</ref> Wisdom is seen as a light, that casts away darkness, and "its dictates must be observed under all circumstances"<ref>{{cite book|last=Browne|first=ʻAbduʹl-Bahá ; translated by Edward G.|title=A traveler's narrative.|year=1980|publisher=Bahá'i Publ. Trust|location=Wilmette, Ill.|isbn=0877431345|page=46|edition=New and corr. ed.}}</ref> , other concepts associated with wisdom and being wise are considering "the regard of place and the utterance of discourse according to measure and state" and not believing or accepting what other people say so easily.<ref>{{cite book|last=Browne|first=ʻAbduʹl-Bahá ; translated by Edward G.|title=A traveler's narrative.|year=1980|publisher=Bahá'i Publ. Trust|location=Wilmette, Ill.|isbn=0877431345|edition=New and corr. ed.}}</ref>
+
